Posts.Content: Sorry to have you joining our club! But it is great that you found it! There is tons of info and support here. You need to be in very good health to do the DaVinci surgery. They turn you upside down, and, that is for 2-4 hours surgery time. Your doctor will be advise you on that. I do not know about the hormone therapy, so someone will chime in on that. Radiation... I went through the DaVinci surgery (62), and then had to go through radiation.... all clear now. Keep in mind that if you have radiation first, you cannot have the surgery afterwards. The treatments are painless and easy. I did not do the proton radiation. Check out the stickies at the top of the forum. It will help you with info on the various treatments. Good luck.
Posts.Signature: Over the years, PSA was slowly going up.... Once past 4.0, it began to take off Jan 2013 5.4 April 2013 7.6 Biopsy 3+3 1 core pos 1 core maybe Robotic surgery June 2013 Post 3+4 cancer close to edge but not broken through PSA Sep 2013 .01, Dec 2013 .02, Feb 2014 .04, May 2014 .07 Salvage radiation 40 sessions begin July 2014 October 2014 treatment is complete. Cancer free. PSA <.01 / not detectable

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Hi. I had the DaVinci prostatectomy June 2013. I had a post PSA reading of .02 (Jan 2014). My doctor was concerned for he said he expected a <.02. At the office visit he was even suggesting radiation as an option. YIKES! I had another test last week (April 2014), and the # has gone to .04 I will be seeing him in a few days... I am 62 years old. I do not remember all the results/pre tests, but after the operation he did say the cancer was worse than the biopsy indicated - as expected. He also said that the cancer was "close" to the wall of the prostate, but it did not break the wall of the prostate. My father had prostate cancer. He went the radiation route (1980 ish), and ended up with a bag for both pee and poo, which I do not want to go through. Options that I read about do not look good and I really worry about the radiation operation. Any suggestions or advice? Are my numbers that bad?? Thanks much.
Posts.Title: Post surgery PSA numbers.... any guidance appreciated.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Brave. I am going to him again on Thursday, so will post then. The last time I went (3 mos ago), he was already talking radiation soon. Now, I'll probably find that he has everything scheduled.... lol. If anything, I do plan on getting another opinion.
Posts.Title: Post surgery PSA numbers.... any guidance appreciated.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the input. You guys are great. This forum really helps a lot. BTW, I was Gleason (3+3) before the operation.... post mortem on the prostate was (4+3). I went to the Doc today.... He again urged me to do the radiation. He said he was not concerned with the doubling of the PSA , since the numbers were so small, but he did say that the results indicate to him that there is some cancer cells remaining. We discussed the radiation and what was involved... he thought the comment made earlier about the shotgun and sighted rifle was a perfect analogy.... They have come a long way. For now, we have decided to have another blood test in 6 weeks. In the meantime I can check on the doctor for the radiation treatment, and can get a second opinion if I wish.... I think this is a good approach. I am getting past the radiation stigma that I have from my father's experience. If the numbers rise, I will do radiation. If they stay steady... we will just keep doing the tests. Thanks again to all!

Posts.Title: Post surgery PSA numbers.... any guidance appreciated.

Posts.Content: I have had the Robotic surgery, so this is an "after the fact" comment/question. It also may help those that are going to have surgery too. I had extreme pain with the catheter. Every move I made it hurt - lots. Stupid me, I never asked the doctor about it... I just assumed that the pain was normal... Why not? You have a tube stuck up your thingy. So, for those that could have this issue, and for my info, is there something that could have been done? I saw a post about cream or something.... damn I wish I thought of asking after the operation... Thanks,
Posts.Title: Catheter Painful.... what to do?

Posts.Content: Yes, it was at the tip. Damn, I never put anything on it... just never occurred to me. Turning or moving? Hell no, any movement was killing me. It's funny now. Now that I think back, the nurse that got me ready to go home was not used to arranging the catheter bag, or even hooking it up. Thus, she wouldn't know enough (but should have) to tell me what to do about any irritation. WOW I put up with 8 days of hell......but it is over now....
Posts.Title: Catheter Painful.... what to do?

Posts.Content: I agree with Jim215. I seem to be in the same boat as he. I would opt again for the ultra sensitive test from time to time.

Posts.Title: Post-surgery PSA tests: ultra-sensitive or regular?

Posts.Content: Wow, sorry... I did not notice your question earlier. FYI, yes, my post op PSA was .01, then .02, then .04, then .07 At .07 we went for the salvage radiation. I'm done with the treatment, and the PSA is now at <.02 which is considered perfect! Odd though... originally, the test result of <.01 was considered cancer free, where now <.02 is now the base. I'll take it.. and get rechecked on a regular basis.

Posts.Title: Post-surgery PSA tests: ultra-sensitive or regular?

Posts.Content: Guess this is telling us to just get out and have a walk in the sun.
Posts.Title: Vitamin D

Posts.Content: First, check out the sticky at the beginning of the forum regarding the surgery. You will get through it OK. That's what they told me too. For me, the lessons learned are: Only eat soft foods after the surgery. I found pudding and fresh fruit to be my friend. Your first BM is supposed to be a bit rough, but it was absolutely fine for me!! Call the doctor's office if you have pain. I ASSUMED that it would be painful, and ended up putting up with catheter pain for 10 days! The hospital did not give me proper instructions on dealing with the catheter. Best wishes!

Posts.Title: Rude Uro Receptionist

Posts.Content: I had the salvage radiation. You need to be able to control your bladder when you have the radiation. If your bladder is empty, they cannot do the radiation. Get that working, and there is nothing to it.
